newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan state firms told to halt overseas projects.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan state firms told to halt overseas projects.

text.p: Taiwan's Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang on Friday asked state-owned companies to freeze their overseas investment projects until the domestic economy recovers, state-funded Central News Agency reported.

The agency quoted Wang as saying state firms' overseas projects, except for those with special government approval, should be put on hold until local investment climate improves and the economic situation recovers.
Wang said state firms should move towards internationalisation in the future, but Taiwan's economy should come first at the present stage.
Echoing Wang's comments, Pan Wen-yen, president of Taiwan's Chinese Petroleum, told a news conference that the state oil monopoly had put 12 of its 18 major overseas projects on hold.

Taiwan's gross domestic product grew a below-target 5.61 percent in the third quarter, but the statistics bureau predicted that the fourth-quarter GDP would reach 6.6 percent due to surging trade and rising domestic investment and consumption.
